--- name: Preferences & Utility --- ## Where Does Demand Come From? Imagine the market for coffee on campus - Additionally, imagine that the only other good that can be purchased is boba - On a basic level, [demand for coffee]{.hii} is derived from individual's choosing how to divide their income between coffee and boba ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggplot2) # Create data for the supply and demand curves quantity <- c(10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60) price_supply <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6) price_demand <- c(6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1) # Create a data frame curve_data <- data.frame(quantity, price_supply, price_demand) # Create the plot ggplot(curve_data, aes(x = quantity)) + geom_line(aes(y = price_supply), color = "blue", lwd = 2, linetype = "solid") + geom_line(aes(y = price_demand), color = "red", lwd = 2, linetype = "solid") + labs( y = "Price", x = "Quantity" ) + theme_minimal() + annotate("text", x = 60, y = 5.65, label = "S", color = "blue", size = 8) + annotate("text", x = 60, y = 1.3, label = "D", color = "red", size = 8) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](021-preferences-utility_files/figure-html/supply-demand-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: --- ## Where Does Demand Come From? This is the problem we will be dealing with through the first half of the course > How does an individual allocate a [finite amount of resources]{.hii} between [two goods]{.hii}? . . .
[Note:]{.h .note} There are clearly more than just two goods out there, so how can this be useful? [The main critique I always hear about economics courses is that they're unrealistic. That's mostly true, but we can learn about the aggregate by simplifying and making assumptions]{.h .note} --- ## Where Does Demand Come From? - We will frame the decisions as a two-good model where you may choose between: - Food and durable consumption - Leisure (not working) and consumption (paid for by earning a wage) - Consumption now and consumption later > [The key takeaway here is that we can frame many important choices as "two-good" decisions]{.h .note} - This makes things simpler for us to solve while still maintaining some sense of the real world --- ## Determinants of Consumption Consumption of any single good has two parts: - How it [BENEFITS]{.hii} the consumer - We call this [UTILITY]{.hii} - What it [COSTS]{.hii} the consumer - What we give up to purchase the good . . . Let's see what this means through a 1-good example $\rightarrow$ Beer - Imagine the following scenario: - You just arrived at the bar and have had zero drinks so far - Each beer costs the same: $4 ::: {.notes} Beer is a great example of a good with complicated benefits ::: --- ## Beer {.smaller} | Number of Beers | Overall Level of Happiness | Change in Level of Happiness | |:---------------:|:---------------------------:|:-----------------------------:| | 0 | 0 | - | | 1 | 10 | 10 | | 2 | 25 | 15 | | 3 | 35 | 10 | | 4 | 40 | 5 | | 5 | 42 | 3 | | 6 | 30 | -12 | . . . :::: {.columns} :::: {.column width="50%"} If beer were free, how many beers should this person drink? ::: {.fragment } [$$5$$]{.hi} ::: :::: :::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.fragment} Now recall that beer costs $4, how many beers should this person drink? ::: {.fragment} [$$4$$]{.hi} ::: ::: :::: :::: --- ## Intuition Behind "Choice" in Economics You [cannot]{.hi-red} simply find the consumption amount that makes you the happiest. [But why?]{.hi} . . . > The goal is to maximize your [utility]{.hii} whilst acknowledging you have [constraints]{.hii} > > The choice is simple: [consume an additional unit until the cost of doing so outweighs the benefit]{.hii}
. . . [Commit this idea to memory: it is the crux of economics and drives everything we will be doing]{.hi .note} [We maximize utility up to the point that it does not make sense to do so]{.hi .note} --- ## Back to Beer {.smaller} | Number of Beers | Overall Level of Happiness | Change in Level of Happiness | |:---------------:|:---------------------------:|:-----------------------------:| | 0 | 0 | - | | 1 | 10 | 10 | | 2 | 25 | 15 | | 3 | 35 | 10 | | 4 | 40 | 5 | | 5 | 42 | 3 | | 6 | 30 | -12 | Some Questions: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - What is the marginal benefit: - When you have not consumed any beer? - When you have already consumed 3 beers? - When you have already consumed 5 beers? ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - What is the marginal cost of beer? - Does it change as we consume more? ::: :::: --- ## Being and Thinking at the Margin We found two important values: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - [Marginal Benefit (MB)]{.hi} ::: {.fragment} The additional benefit gained for an added unit of consumption ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - [Marginal Cost (MC)]{.hi} ::: {.fragment} The additional cost paid for an added unit of consumption ::: ::: :::: . . . We can describe the decision-making process in a more formal manner: - Initially: [MB]{.hi-green} > [MC]{.hi-red} $\rightarrow$ Consume more! - Eventually: [MB]{.hi-green} < [MC]{.hi-red} $\rightarrow$ We went too far! - At some point: [MB]{.hi-green} = [MC]{.hi-red} $\rightarrow$ Just right! > [Ask yourself: Why must they be equal?]{.hi .note} --- ## What's Going On? Graphically ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load the ggplot2 library if not already loaded library(ggplot2) # Create a data frame with x values data <- data.frame(x = c(0,1,2,3,4,5,6), y = c(0,10,25,35,40,42,30)) # Create the ggplot object utility <- ggplot(data, aes(x = x, y = y)) + geom_line(color = "black", size = 2) + xlim(0,6) + labs( x = "Beers", y = "Utility" ) + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. â„¹ Please use `linewidth` instead. ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} utility ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](021-preferences-utility_files/figure-html/beer-utility-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: . . . What matters for choice is the [marginal benefit]{.hi} of an additional beer In other words, what matters is the change in [utility]{.hii} that occurs as we move to the right on the graph . . . > [Recall: A change in $y$ as $x$ increases is the derivative]{.h .note} --- ## What's Going On? Graphically - Derivatives ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} utility ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](021-preferences-utility_files/figure-html/beer-utility-derivative-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: The derivative of this function is the [marginal benefit]{.hi} of beer [This is why derivatives are important]{.h .note} We can use derivatives to figure out the optimal amount to consume --- ## What's Going On? Graphically - MB & MC ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} utility ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](021-preferences-utility_files/figure-html/beer-utility-derivative1-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: > [Recall:]{.hi .note} The optimal choice is the point where [MB]{.hi-green} = [MC]{.hi-red} > The [MC]{.hi-red} = 4. So we would choose the quantity of beers where [MB]{.hi-green} = 4 --- ## What's Going On? Mathematically The utility function of beer we've been using is: $$U(x) = -x^{2} + 12x$$ [Let's practice:]{.h} What would the optimal consumption amount be if the cost of beer is $2? . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} [Find the Marginal Benefit]{.hi} ::: {.fragment} $$ MU_{x} = \dfrac{\partial U}{\partial x} = -2x + 12 $$ ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.fragment} [Set the MB equal to MC]{.hi} ::: ::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} MB &= MC \\ -2x + 12 &= 2 \\ 2x &= 10 \\ x &= 5 \end{align*} ::: ::: :::: --- ## A Two-Good Problem The beer example was fairly straightforward. But we will be dealing with making choices between two goods. Before we dive in, a couple of things to consider are: . . . - When we spend our resources on one good, it cannot be spent on something else - Because we are making decisions amongst both things, we need a [cost relationship]{.hi} between them . . . - We do not measure our happiness (utility) in dollars - We need to find a way to choose without directly comparing costs and benefits across goods --- ## Enter Utility Functions {.smaller} A [Utility Function]{.hi} is a function of two variables: $$U = f(x,y)$$ [Some facts:]{.h} - $x$ and $y$ are the (positive) amounts of goods you consume - The function converts $x$ and $y$ to happiness (utility) from consuming the two goods . . . [For Example:]{.h} - Let's say that the utility I receive from [kombucha (K)]{.h} and [hop water (H)]{.h} can be modeled as: $$U = f(K,H) = 10K + 2H$$ - Before, we were only interested in the slope of Beer - Now, we are interested in the [slopes]{.hii} of both kombucha & hop water --- ## Utility Functions - kombucha & hop water $$U = f(K,H) = 10K + 2H$$ For a function of two variables there are [two slopes]{.hi} - One for each [partial derivative]{.hii} which we will call [Marginal Utilities]{.hii} . . . - In the [kombucha (K)]{.h} and [hop water (H)]{.h} example we will have: - The [Marginal Utility of kombucha]{.hii} [($MU_{B}$)]{.h} - The [Marginal Utility of hop water]{.hii} [($MU_{H}$)]{.h} . . . > What are the Marginal Utilities of kombucha and hop water? --- ## Utility Functions - PB&J Now find the Marginal Utilities for Peanut Butter and Jelly $$U = f(P,J) = P^{2} \cdot J$$ . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} [Peanut Butter]{.hi} ::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} MU_{P} &= 2P^{2-1} \cdot J = 2PJ \\ \end{align*} ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} [Jelly]{.hi} ::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} MU_{J} &= P^{2} \cdot J^{1-1} = P^{2} \\ \end{align*} ::: ::: :::: --- ## What do Utility Functions even Mean? They help us represent how people feel about goods $x$ and $y$ There are certain properties that help us determine: . . . - Do I [like or dislike]{.hi} $x$? - Does [how much I like]{.hi} $x$ depend on [how much $x$ I already have]{.hi}? - Does [how much I like]{.hi} $x$ depend on [how much $y$ I have]{.hi}? . . . > [We can understand these properties by looking at the marginal utilities!]{.h .note .big} --- ## Utility Functions - Do I Like or Dislike $x$? > [If I consume more $x$, how does my utility move?]{.h .note .big} Beyond graphing the utility function, we need to find a way to answer this formally and mathematically . . . We can look at the [sign of the derivative]{.hi} - If the derivative of $U$ with respect to (w.r.t.) $x$ is: . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} [Positive]{.hi-green} ::: {.fragment} I like $x$ ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} [Negative]{.hi-red} ::: {.fragment} I dislike $x$ ::: ::: :::: --- ## Like or Dislike - Example Given my utility curve for [kombucha (K)]{.h} and [hop water (H)]{.h}, what do I like or dislike? $$U = f(K,H) = 10K + 2H$$ . . .

:::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} I like [kombucha]{.h} ::: {.fragment} $$MU_{K} = 10 > 0$$ ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} I like [hop water]{.h} ::: {.fragment} $$MU_{H} = 2 > 0$$ ::: ::: :::: --- ## Does How Much I like $x$ Depend on How Much I Already Have? > [Remember to think at the margin]{.h .note} Is each additional unit of $x$ bring me [more]{.hi-green}, [less]{.hi-red}, or [equal]{.hi-teal} happiness as the previous unit? . . .
This is slightly trickier to figure out, but we still use marginal utility logic - In fact, we will use what is called the [Second Derivative]{.hi} - Mathematically, this is the [derivative]{.h} of $MU_{x}$ w.r.t. $x$ and we ask: - Is this [second derivative]{.h} [positive]{.hi-green}, [negative]{.hi-red}, or [zero]{.hi-teal}? --- ## Depend on How Much I Already Have - Example My utility for [Cookies]{.h} and [Milk]{.h}: $$U = f(C,M) = C^{1/2}M^{1/2}$$ . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} [Cookies]{.h} ::: {.fragment .tiny} $MU_{c} = \dfrac{1}{2} \cdot C^{-1/2} \cdot M^{1/2}$ $MU_{cc} = \dfrac{-1}{2} \cdot \dfrac{1}{2} \cdot C^{-1/2 - 1} \cdot M^{1/2}$ $MU_{cc} = \dfrac{-1}{4} \cdot \dfrac{1}{C^{3/2}} \cdot M^{1/2}$ $MU_{cc} = \dfrac{-M^{1/2}}{4C^{3/2}}$ ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} [Milk]{.h} ::: {.fragment} $U_{mm} = \dfrac{-C^{1/2}}{4M^{3/2}}$ :::
::: {.fragment} $MU_{cc}$ is [negative]{.hi-red} so we can say that [Cookies]{.h} have a Decreasing Marginal Utility ::: ::: :::: --- ## Does How Much I Like $x$ Depend on How Much $y$ I Have? This one is more straightforward: Does the marginal utility of $x$ depend on $y$? - Mathematically, we take the derivative of $MU_{x}$ w.r.t. to $y$, and vice-versa. - This is called the [cross-partial derivative]{.h} - Notationally, we have: $MU_{xy}$ Where we can determine the order of derivatives by looking at the subscript: - $x$ is first, and $y$ is the second derivative --- ## Depend on How Much of the Other Good I Have - Example How about this utility for Peanut Butter and Jelly $$U = f(P,J) = P^{2} \cdot J$$ . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} [Peanut Butter]{.hi} ::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} MU_{P} &= 2P^{2-1} \cdot J = 2PJ \\ MU_{PJ} &= 2P \cdot J^{1-1} = 2P \end{align*} ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} [Jelly]{.hi} ::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} MU_{J} &= P^{2} \cdot J^{1-1} = P^{2} \\ MU_{JP} &= P^{2} = 2P \end{align*} ::: ::: :::: . . . > [Notice that the cross-partials are the same and this will always be the case for any utility function!]{.note .h} --- ## Meaning of a Utility Function What are Utility Functions? . . . - They are a flexible tool that help us describe the relationship between two goods and the utility (happiness) you gain from them . . . - They allow us to get a good intuition of how we can change function properties so they relate to the choice we are attempting to model . . . - Let's think about some goods and decide what the utility function should look like --- ## Modeling with Utility Functions Let's consider [Homework]{.hi} and [Pizza]{.hi} . . . - First, we decide whether the good is desirable [(good)]{.hi-green} or undesirable [(bad)]{.hi-red} ::: {.fragment} - I'll make the bold assumption that [Homework]{.hi} is a bad and that [Pizza]{.hi} is a good ::: ::: {.fragment} > [Note: This implies that the marginal utilities are $MU_{H} < 0$ and $MU_{P} > 0$]{.h .note} ::: --- ## Modeling with Utility Functions - Example [Homework]{.hi} is a [bad]{.hi-red} and [Pizza]{.hi} is a [good]{.hi-green} . . . Let's also set the following requirements: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} The [marginal disutility]{.hi-red} of [homework]{.hi} is larger when I have more of it ::: {.fragment} $MU_{H}$ is decreasing in $H \; \rightarrow \;$ We need an $H$ in $MU_{H}$ ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} The [marginal utility]{.hi-green} of [pizza]{.hi} is smaller when I have more of it ::: {.fragment} $MU_{P}$ becomes smaller as I have more $P \; \rightarrow \;$ We need an $H$ in $MU_{H}$ $MU_{P}$ does [**not**]{.h} depend on [homework]{.hi} $MU_{P}$ does not have an $H$ ::: ::: :::: . . . > [Attempt creating a utility function with the above characteristics]{.h .note} --- ## Modeling our Homework and Pizza {.smaller} Here's my version: $$U(H,P) = -H^{2} + ln(P)$$ Now let's prove that it meets the requirements . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} [Homework]{.hi} is a [bad]{.hi-red} and must be worse the more I have of interested :::: {.fragment} $$MU_{H} = -2H < 0$$ $$MU_{HH} = -2 <0$$ :::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} [Pizza]{.hi} is a [good]{.hi-green}, I get less joy from it the more I have, and it does not depend on how much [homework]{.hi} I have :::: {.fragment} $$MU_{P} = \dfrac{1}{P} > 0 $$ $$MU_{PP} = \dfrac{-1}{P^{2}} < 0$$ $$MU_{PH} = 0 = MU_{HP}$$ :::: ::: :::: --- ## Meaning of a Utility function The single most important property of a utility function is that we can measure [**the relative preference for one good over the other**]{.h} - We can measure [how many units of $y$ would you give up to get one more unit of $x$?]{.hi} - We call this the [Marginal Rate of Substitution (MRS)]{.hii} $$MRS = \dfrac{MU_{x}}{MU_{y}}$$ --- ## Marginal Rate of Substitution (MRS) Here we are talking about the relative preference of $x$ over $y$, but how? . . . - Consider $U = f(x,y) = 4x + 2y$ - You get 4 units of utility for each $x \; \rightarrow \; 4$ - You get 2 units of utility for each $y \; \rightarrow \; 2$ - We can say that each $x$ is twice as valuable as each $y$ . . . Using our MRS formula we have: $$MRS = \dfrac{MU_{x}}{MU_{y}} = \dfrac{4}{2} = 2$$ --- ## Types of Utility Functions In Economics, we mainly deal with 4 types of functions, each with its set of properties and tricks . . . - Cobb-Douglas - Quasi-linear - Perfect Substitutes - Perfect Complements --- ## Cobb-Douglas $$U(x,y) = x^{a}y^{b}$$ > [**Find the MRS of this general function**]{.note .h} . . . $$MRS = \dfrac{MU_{x}}{MU_{y}} = \dfrac{ax^{a-1}y^{b}}{bx^{a}y^{b-1}} = \dfrac{a}{b} \cdot \dfrac{x^{a-1-a}}{y^{b-1-b}} = \dfrac{a}{b} \cdot \dfrac{x^{-1}}{y^{-1}} = \dfrac{a}{b} \cdot \dfrac{y}{x}$$ . . . > [**The MRS for a Cobb-Douglas will always look like**]{.note .h} > > $$\dfrac{a}{b} \cdot \dfrac{y}{x}$$ --- ## Cobb-Douglas: Keys to Remember $$MRS = \dfrac{a}{b} \cdot \dfrac{y}{x}$$ - The MRS is a ratio of $y$ to $x$, multiplied by a constant - MRS is your [willingness to trade $y$ for $x$]{.h} - As you get more $x$, the MRS goes down - As you get more $y$, the MRS goes up --- ## Cobb-Douglas - Example $$U(x,y) = x^{3}y^{1/2}$$ > [**Find the MRS of this utility function**]{.note .h} . . . $$MRS = \dfrac{MU_{x}}{MU_{y}} = \dfrac{3x^{2}y^{1/2}}{1/2x^{3}y^{-1/2}} = \dfrac{3}{1/2} \cdot \dfrac{y^{1/2}y^{1/2}}{x^{3}x^{-2}} = 6 \cdot \dfrac{y}{x}$$ . . . If we recall that $MRS = \dfrac{a}{b} \cdot \dfrac{y}{x}$ then we can take a shortcut: $$MRS = \dfrac{a}{b} \cdot \dfrac{y}{x} \rightarrow \dfrac{3}{1/2} \cdot \dfrac{y}{x} = 6 \cdot \dfrac{y}{x}$$ ::: {.notes} Introduce log transformation here ::: --- ## Quasi-Linear $$U(x,y) = a \cdot ln(x) + b \cdot y$$ Where $a \cdot ln(x)$ is the ["quasi"]{.h} part and $b \cdot y$ is the ["linear"]{.h} part > [**Find the MRS of this general function**]{.note .h} . . . $$MRS = \dfrac{MU_{x}}{MU_{y}} = \dfrac{a/x}{b} = \dfrac{a}{b} \cdot \dfrac{1}{x}$$ --- ## Quasi-Linear: Keys to Remember $$MRS = \dfrac{a}{b} \cdot \dfrac{1}{x}$$ - The MRS is a constant times $1/x$ - As you get more $x$, the MRS decreases - As you get more $y$, the MRS remains the same --- ## Quasi-Linear - Example $$U(x,y) = 1/3 \cdot ln(x) + y$$ > [**Find the MRS of this utility function**]{.note .h} . . . $$MRS = \dfrac{MU_{x}}{MU_{y}} = \dfrac{1/3 \cdot 1/x}{1} = \dfrac{1}{3} \cdot \dfrac{1}{x}$$ . . . Using our shortcut we get: $$MRS = \dfrac{a}{b} \cdot \dfrac{1}{x} = \dfrac{1/3}{1} \cdot \dfrac{1}{x} = \dfrac{1}{3} \cdot \dfrac{1}{x}$$ --- ## Perfect Substitutes $$U(x,y) = a \cdot x + b \cdot y$$ > [**Find the MRS of this general function**]{.note .h} . . . $$MRS = \dfrac{MU_{x}}{MU_{y}} = \dfrac{a}{b}$$ ### Keys to Remember - MRS is a constant --- ## Perfect Substitutes - Example $$U(x,y) = 6x + \dfrac{1}{2} y $$ > [**Find the MRS of this utility function**]{.note .h} . . . $$MRS = \dfrac{MU_{x}}{MU_{y}} = \dfrac{6}{1/2} = 12$$ . . . And our shortcut shows: $$MRS = \dfrac{6}{1/2} = 12$$ --- ## Perfect Complements $$U(x,y) = \min \{a \cdot x, b \cdot y \}$$ This utility function requires a different form of intuition Let's first think of a simple example: . . . Imagine we are trying to make some hot chocolate which requires 1 pack of chocolate powder and 12 oz of milk $$U(x,y) = \min \{1 \, choco, 12oz \, milk \}$$ . . . You check your kitchen and find that there are 3 packs of chocolate powder and you have 15 oz of milk in your fridge . . . > [**How many hot chocolates can we make?**]{.h .note} --- ## Perfect Complements Intuition These are goods that [**have to be consumed together in an exact proportion**]{.h} in order to produce any utility > There is no MRS, so we use a property called the [No-Waste Condition]{.hi}: > > $$U(x,y) = \min \{a \cdot x, b \cdot y \}$$ > > $$a \cdot x = b \cdot y$$ --- ## Perfect Complements: Keys to Remember - MRS is not defined (We cannot take a derivative) - We can use the [No-Waste Condition]{.hi}: - When $a \cdot x < b \cdot y$ you will give up any $y$ you can to get more $x$ - When $a \cdot x > b \cdot y$ you will give up any $x$ you can to get $y$ --- ## Perfect Complements - Example $$U(x,y) = \min \{ \dfrac{x}{2}, \dfrac{y}{4} \}$$ > [**Find the No-Waste Condition of this utility function**]{.note .h} . . . No-Waste Condition is $\dfrac{x}{2} = \dfrac{y}{4} \rightarrow 4x = 2y \rightarrow 2x = y$ . . . We can say: - If $2x > y \; \rightarrow \;$ Too much $x$, so we would trade some $x$ for some $y$ - If $2x < y \; \rightarrow \;$ Too much $y$, so we would trade some $y$ for some $x$ --- ## Bundles When you have a utility function of two goods, any given combination of those two goods is called a [Bundle]{.hi} - Every [bundle]{.hi} has an associated utility level Take the following utility function and bundles $$U(x,y) = x^{2}y$$ . . . :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} Bundle 1 is (3,2) :::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} U(3,2) &= 3^{2} \cdot 2 \\ &= 9 \cdot 2 = 18 \end{align*} :::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} Bundle 2 is (1,0) :::: {.fragment} \begin{align*} U(1,0) &= 1^{2} \cdot 0 \\ &= 1 \cdot 0 = 0 \end{align*} :::: ::: :::: --- ## Bundles & Axioms of Preferences :::: {.notes} Let's first define what an Axiom is - A proposition that is assumed to be true without proof for the sake of studying the consequences that follow from it :::: We will use the following axioms about preferences between bundles to ensure logical consistency . . . - Completeness . . . - "More is Better" . . . - Transitivity . . . > [These come from economic theory so they will help you think like an economist but do not think this tells us how people behave]{.h .note} . . . > [We are attempting to successfully predict behavior, so we will simply assume that everyone behaves accordingly]{.h .note} --- ## Completeness We say that preferences are always [complete]{.hi}. So when comparing bundles A and B, you can always say one of the following: . . . - I prefer A to B ($A \succeq B$) - I prefer B to A ($B \succeq A$) - I am indifferent between A and B ($A \sim B$) . . . This allows us to compare and order any pair of bundles --- ## "More is Better" Or at least more is no worse than less . . . In general, if a good is desirable we will want more of it - However, sometimes products can be bads (instead of goods) and we would, obviously, want less of those --- ## Transitivity Preferences are transitive. This means that when comparing bundles A, B, and C you can get logical orderings through rankings: . . . - If you prefer B to A ($B \succeq A$) and C to B ($C \succeq B$) then you must prefer C to A ($C \succeq A$) . . . ![](Images\Transitivity-line.png){fig-align="center"} --- ## Transitivity What would this graph mean? ![](Images\Transitivity-Equal-line.png){fig-align="center"} . . . All bundles are preferred equally! --- ## Preferences Assumptions All of these are necessary to understand utility funcitons and be able to graph them To do so we first need to learn about [Indifference Curves]{.hii}
